content: Circumstellar dust is cosmic dust around a star, often in the form of a spherical shell or disc, responsible for extinction and infrared excess in some stars. The composition of this dust, studied in astrominerology, includes crystalline silicate and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon. The motion of circumstellar dust is governed by stellar gravity and radiation pressure. In the Solar System, it causes the zodiacal light.

content: A dark nebula, also known as an absorption nebula, is a dense interstellar cloud that blocks visible light from objects behind it. This is caused by interstellar dust grains in molecular clouds. Large complexes of dark nebulae are associated with Giant Molecular Clouds, while isolated small ones are called Bok globules. These clouds appear dark due to sub-micrometre-sized dust particles coated with frozen carbon monoxide and nitrogen, blocking visible light. They are also made up of molecular hydrogen, atomic helium, and other relatively transparent materials. Dark nebulae are important in the formation of stars a

A dust lane is a dense, obscuring cloud of interstellar dust seen as a dark swath against a brighter object, often a galaxy. This phenomenon is typically seen in spiral galaxies like the Milky Way when viewed from the edge. The dust reduces the light from the galaxy by several magnitudes, making it impossible to see the stars behind t

content: Intergalactic dust, found between galaxies in intergalactic space, has been studied since 1949. It varies in distribution and can affect distance measurements to other galaxies. Intergalactic dust clouds have been known to exist around some galaxies since the 1960s, and at least four have been discovered near the Milky Way by the 1980s, such as the Okroy Cloud. The dust can absorb and re-emit visible light, leading to greate

content:
The interplanetary dust cloud, or zodiacal cloud, is a collection of cosmic dust particles that fills the space between planets in the Solar System. This dust has been studied for years to understand its nature and relationship to larger bodies. Various methods are used to measure space dust.

Interplanetary dust particles in the Solar System scatter sunlight and emit thermal radiation, which is the most prominent feature of the night sky's radiation, with wavelengths ranging 5–50 μm. The sizes of dust particles near Earth typically range 10–100 μm. The total mass of the interplanetary dust cloud is approximately 3.5×1016 kg, or the mass of an asteroid of radius 15 km. This dust cloud is visible as the zodiacal light in a moonless and naturally dark sky, best seen sunward during astronomical twilight.

Pioneer spacecraft observations

An interstellar cloud is a denser region of gas, plasma, and dust in the space between star systems in galaxies. These clouds can be neutral, ionized, or molecular, and are formed by the gas and dust from a red giant in its later life. They are also referred to as H I, H II, or simply molecular clouds, depending on their composition.
see_also: List of molecules in interstellar space

content: A molecular cloud, also known as a stellar nursery if star formation is occurring, is an interstellar cloud with the density and size to permit absorption nebulae, the formation of molecules (most commonly H2), and the formation of H II regions. Molecular hydrogen is difficult to detect, so the presence of H2 is often determined by observing carbon monoxide (CO). Clumps within molecular clouds have higher density and contain many gas cores, and they are the beginning of star form

content: The Poynting–Robertson effect, or P-R drag, is a process where solar radiation causes a dust grain orbiting a star to lose angular momentum, leading to slow spiraling into the star. Dust particles from 1 μm to 1 mm in diameter are affected while larger dust likely collides with other objects first. Poynting first described the effect in 1903, based on the luminiferous aether theory, which was later replaced by the theories of relativity. Robertson later described the ef

Presolar grains are tiny solid grains of interstellar matter that formed before the Sun. They originated from outflowing gases of earlier presolar stars and have unique isotopic compositions specific to their parent star. The study of presolar grains falls under cosmochemistry and meteoritics, as their isotopic signatures provide evidence of specific astrophysical nuclear processes. This

Space dust measurement is the study of small extraterrestrial particles, known as micrometeoroids or interplanetary dust particles (IDPs), in the Solar System. These micrometer to sub-millimeter-sized particles are made of materials like silicates, metals, and carbon compounds. Researching space dust helps us understand the Solar System's composition and evolution, as well as the potential hazards it poses to spacecraft. Advanced scien

Hundreds of contractors were tasked with creating modules, trusses, and experiments for the station. The global cooperation of sixteen countries presented engineering challenges, including language, culture, and political differences, as well as varying engineering processes and measurement standards. content:
Planetary-surface construction involves building artificial habitats and structures on planetary surfaces, which can be divided into three classes:

• Class I: Self-contained habitats that can be immediately used upon delivery.
• Class II: Prefabricated kit-of-parts that are assembled on the surface.
• Class III: Structures made using local resources and integrated Earth components.

Class I structures are tested on Earth and provide basic facilities for initial missions to other planets. Class II structures can expand the initial facilities and be assembled before or after a crew arrives. Class III structures support a larger population and enable local building material production.

To develop the technology for these phases, Cohen and Kennedy (1997) suggest exploring robust robotic systems for construction and autonomy. They also stress the need to adapt structural components for robotic assembly and determine appropriate levels of modularity, assembly, and component packaging, as well as the development of experimental construc

content: Human spaceflight, also known as manned or crewed spaceflight, involves sending a crew or passengers onboard a spacecraft, which can be operated by the crew or remotely from the ground or autonomously. Those trained for spaceflight are astronauts, cosmonauts, taikonauts, or spaceflight participants. The first human in space was Yuri Gagarin in 1961, followed by Alan Shepard in the same year. Humans traveled to the Moon as part of the Apollo program and have been continuously present in space on the International Space Station for over 23 years. China joined human spaceflight in 2003. Since the Apollo 17 mission in 1972, no human has traveled beyond low Earth orbit. Currently, the United States, Russia, and China are the only countries with human spaceflight programs, although non-governmental spaceflight companies have been developing their own programs for space tourism and commercial research. content: Kosmos 110 was a Soviet spacecraft launched in 1966 with two dogs aboard. It was a popular and eye-catching experiment in the series of Russian Kosmos satellites.

The growth of plants in outer space has sparked scientific interest, with plants being taken into space in low Earth orbit to be grown in controlled environments. They are consumed as food, produce oxygen, and help control cabin humidity, providing a psychological benefit to space crews. While initially for scientific studies, NASA plans to use space farming to feed astronauts and provide psychological benefits for long-term space flight. Challenges include growing plants without gravity, nutrient supply, and microbiological interactions in soil-based substrates. In 2017, Chinese cabbage was grown aboard the ISS for crew consumption. This concept dates back to the 1869 short story "The Brick Moon". The Apollo Moon tree project also contributed to forestry and a country's bicentennial celebration.

content: The Apollo 11 goodwill messages consist of statements from leaders of 73 countries, engraved on a silicon disc the size of a 50-cent piece, that was left on the Moon in 1969 by the Apollo 11 astronauts. The disc also includes names of Congress leadership, NASA committees, and top management. The idea was proposed by NASA head Thomas O. Paine and the letters were collected, photographed, and reduced to 1/200 scale ultra microfiche silicon etching. The disc, housed in an aluminum case, was dropped to the surface of the Moon by Buzz Aldrin, and later confirmed to have been placed by Houston.

content:
The Europa Clipper, previously known as Europa Multiple Flyby Mission, is a space probe being developed by NASA for launch in October 2024. It is designed to study Jupiter's moon Europa through a series of flybys while in orbit around Jupiter. This mission is the largest spacecraft NASA has ever developed for a planetary mission and is part of the Planetary Science Division's Large Strategic Science Mission. It will be funded under the Planetary Missions Program Office's Solar System Exploration program as its second flight, and is also supported by the Ocean Worlds Exploration Program.

Europa Clipper will follow up on studies made by the Galileo spacecraft, which indicated the existence of a subsurface ocean underneath Europa's ice crust. Initially conceived as a spacecraft to be injected into orbit around Europa, it was instead decided that it would be safer to inject a spacecraft into an elliptical orbit around Jupiter and make 44 close flybys of the moon, due to the adverse effects of radiation from Jupiter's magnetosphere in Euro

content: Lunar plaques, measuring 9 by 7+5⁄8 inches, were attached to the descent stages of United States Apollo Lunar Modules during lunar landing missions Apollo 11 through Apollo 17. Designed by Jack Kinzler, head of technical services at NASA, the plaques bear facsimiles of the participating astronauts' signatures, including a replacement plaque for Apollo 13. The plaques also feature the signatures of President Richard Nixon, as well as images of Earth's hemispheres and, in the case of Apollo 17, a depiction of the lunar globe. All the plaques were left on the Moon, except for those of Apollo 13.

content: The MarsDial is a sundial used to calibrate Mars lander cameras. It was placed on Spirit and Opportunity rovers with inscriptions in 22 languages. The length and direction of the shadow cast by the stick allows observers to calculate the time of day and determine North. The design team included Bill Nye, Jon Lomberg, and astronomers. Curiosity rover used a spare sundial with new text. The sundial serves as a message artifact for future human explorers to find.

content: Space warfare involves combat in outer space, including ground-to-space, space-to-space, and space-to-ground warfare. It is a sub-genre of science fiction and is regulated by international treaties to limit the installation of space weapon systems. The first practical instance of space warfare occurred in 2023 during the Israel-Hamas War, when Israel's Arrow 2 system intercepted a ballistic missile launched from Yemen. In 2024, Iran launched over 120 ballistic missiles at Israel, marking the first large-scale incident of space weapon use. The United States Space Command existed from 1985 to 2002, merging with the United States Strategic Command. The United States Space Force is now the primary American military space force. The Russian Space Force was replaced by the Russian Aerospace Defence Forces but was reestablished as a component of the Russian Aerospace Forces. content: Human presence in space, including the presence of humans in outer space and on extraterrestrial bodies, can take many forms, from space debris to crewed spacecraft and space stations. It serves a range of purposes, from exploration to commercial use, settlement, and militarization. Achieved through space sciences and astronautics, humans have had a sustained presence in orbit around Earth since 1958 and have continuously crewed the ISS since 2000. However, this increasing presence has also brought the threat of space debris and the need for regulation and mitigation to ensure sustainable access to outer space. Securing this access has been pursued through space law and industry, but sustainability remains a challenge, with efforts to advance long-term sustainability in space activities. The United States sees this as a crucial goal of its contemporary space policy and program, recognizing the need for sustainable outer space activities.

content: A solar gravitational lens (SGL) uses the Sun as a large lens via gravitational lensing to directly image habitable exoplanets. Einstein predicted in 1936 that light rays could converge to a focal point approximately 542 AUs from the Sun. A probe positioned at this distance could use the Sun as a lens to magnify distant objects. The Sun's gravitational field bends light more prominently closer to the Sun, and a proposed probe, SETIsail or FOCAL, could utilize the lens for imaging. NASA physicist Slava Turyshev presented a mission concept for direct imaging and spectroscopy of an exoplanet with a solar gravitational lens, proposing the use of realistic-sized solar sails to achieve the needed high velocity and reach the required distance in 17 years. This proposal was selected for Phase III of NIAC 2020. It is expected that the lens could reconstruct the exoplanet image with 25 km-scale surface resolution in 6 months of integration time, potentially revealing surface features and signs of habitability.

content:
The Space Race was a 20th-century competition between the United States and the Soviet Union to achieve superior spaceflight capability. It had its origins in the nuclear arms race following World War II and peaked with the Moon Race to land on the Moon. Spaceflight achievement was seen as necessary for national security and became part of the symbolism and ideology of the time. 

Public interest in space travel began in 1951 with the publication of a Soviet youth magazine, and the competition officially began in 1955 with the announcement of plans to launch artificial satellites. The Soviet Union gained attention with the successful launch of Sputnik 1 in 1957 and the first human, Yuri Gagarin, into space in 1961. This led US president John F. Kennedy to commit to landing a man on the Moon before the end of the decade, which was achieved in 1969 with the flight of Apollo 11.

The USSR continued to pursue crewed lunar programs, but did not succeed, eventually canceling their program to focus on space stations and exploration of other planets. A period of détente followed with the joint Apollo–Soyuz Test Project in 1975. The collapse of the Soviet Union allowed the US and Russia to end their competition and cooperate on space programs, including the Shuttle–Mir and International Space Station programs in 1993.

content:
Commercial use of space involves providing goods or services with commercial value using equipment sent into Earth orbit or outer space. This includes satellite use, which began in 1962 with Telstar 1 transmitting TV signals. By 2004, global investment in space sectors was $50.8 billion, with 31% of space launches being commercial by 2010. The space economy is projected to reach $1.8 trillion by 2035.

The commercial spaceflight sector primarily generates revenue by launching satellites into Earth's orbit, with the FAA licensing U.S. spaceports and overseeing rocket launches. Global capacity is expanding in Russia, France, and China, with investment in reusable launch vehicles driving innovation. In 2022, 74 FAA-licensed commercial space operations were conducted, with expectations of doubling in the near future.

Commercial satellite manufacturing encompasses non-military, civilian, governmental, and non-profit satellite production, ground equipment manufacturing, satellite subscription services, satellite imagery, telecommunications, navigation systems, and space tourism. Space commerce regulation has faced challenges, but legislation like the U.S. Commercial Space Launch Competitiveness Act aims to clarify ownership and encourage commercial space exploration.

subcategories: List of satellites in geosynchronous orbit

content: Russia's space industry has over 100 companies and 250,000 employees, many originating from Soviet design bureaux and state production companies. After the Soviet Union's dissolution, the industry faced a crisis, but began to recover in the early 2000s through joint-ventures and foreign markets. In the mid-2000s, the industry received increased funding, leading to a new federal space plan and significant growth. RKK Energiya, Khrunichev, TsSKB-Progress, ISS Reshetnev, and NPO Lavochkin are the leading companies. The industry is currently undergoing a major reorganization, with increased state involvement.

content:
印度的太空产业主要由国家印度空间研究组织（ISRO）推动。该产业包括500多家私营供应商和空间部门的各种机构，涵盖商业、研究和其他方面。自21世纪初以来，独立私营机构虽然不多，但已经开始扮演更重要的角色。2023年，印度太空产业占全球太空产业规模的2%-3%，员工超过45,000人。

2021年，印度政府成立了印度空间协会（ISpA），以向私营部门和初创企业开放印度空间产业。拉森及图班、Nelco（塔塔集团）、OneWeb、MapmyIndia和Walchandnagar Industries等多家私营公司是该组织的创始成员。安尼尔·库马尔·巴特中将被任命为ISpA总干事。

当科学家们开始从特里凡得琅的桑巴赤道火箭发射站发射探空火箭时，印度政府涉足太空探索。该太空机构的建立导致SLV-3、ASLV等小型发射器的发展，随后在90年代推出更大的PSLV和GSLV火箭，使印度能够运载更大的有效载荷，并为国际市场进行商业发射。私营公司随后开始成为各种火箭和卫星部件的分包商。在2010年代后期，实行了改革，解放太空领域，并签署了保密协议，导致各种私营太空飞行公司的出现。

截至2019年，印度已为各个外国国家发射了300多颗卫星。2021年初，印度有40多家初创企业处于各种发展阶段，正在开发自己的发射器、设计卫星和其他相关活动。

content: India's Space Industry is primarily driven by ISRO, with over 500 private suppliers and various bodies of the Department of Space involved in commercial, research, and arbitrary activities. In 2023, the industry accounted for $9 billion and employed over 45,000 people, representing 2%-3% of the global space industry. The Government of India launched ISpA in 2021 to open the industry to private sectors and start-ups. Several private companies are founding members of this organisation. India's space exploration began with the launch of sounding rockets from TERLS, leading to the development of small and larger launch vehicles in the 90s. Liberalisation of the space sector and nondisclosure agreements in the late 2010s led to the emergence of various private spaceflight companies. By 2019, India had launched more than 300 satellites for foreign states, and by early 2021, there were more than 40 startups in various stages of developing their

content: The Far Ultraviolet Camera/Spectrograph (UVC) was used by Apollo 16 astronauts on the moon to capture images and spectra in the far ultravi

The High Definition Earth Viewing (HDEV) cameras were delivered to the International Space Station on the SpaceX CRS-3 Mission in April 2014. The system consists of four commercial high definition video cameras mounted on the exterior of the European Space Agency's Columbus laboratory module. It was the first large unpressurized NASA experiment to be delivered by SpaceX. The cameras streamed live video of Earth to be viewed online and on NASA TV, and now play previously-recorded video in a continuous loop on public streaming sites.

The HDEV system was developed by engineers at the Johnson Space Center in Houston, Texas, and designed with the help of high school students through NASA's High Schools United with NASA to Create Hardware program. The cameras were housed in a specific temperature enclosure and exposed to the radiation of space to help NASA determine which cameras work best in outer space.

After over 5 years of operation exceeding its expected lifespan of 1 to 3 years, the HDEV system was removed from the Columbus module in May 2020 and transferred into the Cygnus NG-13 resupply spacecraft for disposal via destructive re-entry at the end of its mission. Following the end of HDEV, two of the International Space Station External High Definition Cameras (EHDCs) have been used to provide video to the HDEV live feed.

content: The International Charter "Space and Major Disasters" is a non-binding agreement that allows for the charitable and humanitarian sharing of satellite data in the event of major disasters. Initiated by the European Space Agency and the French space agency CNES in 1999, it officially began operating in November 2000 after the Canadian Space Agency joined. The charter’s satellite assets have been used for various natural disasters, as well as for non-traditional purposes such as the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 and the West Africa Ebola outbreak. As of 2018, it had been activated 579 times in 125 countries and had 17 member agencies and 34 satellites. It received the prestigious William T. Pecora Award in 2017.

content: Dextre, or the SPDM, is a two-armed robot on the ISS that performs repairs to avoid the need for spacewalks. It was launched in 2008 as part of Canada's contributions to the ISS and is the newest of three Canadian robotic arms. Dextre was designed and manufactured by MDA. In 2011, Dextre completed its first official assignment by unpacking pieces for Kounotori 2 while the crew was sleeping.

content: SPHERES are miniaturized satellites developed by MIT for NASA and US Military. They serve as a test bed for developing critical algorithms for future space missions, with each satellite being an 18-sided polyhedron weighing 4.1 kg. They use CO2-based thrusters and ultrasonic beacons for movement and orientation, and can communicate wirelessly. Three units are currently used in the International Space Station for experiments, and the program is expected to continue until 2017. The SPHERES project has led to the development of Astrobee.

content: Women have been a part of human spaceflight from the beginning, with Soviet Valentina Tereshkova being the first woman to fly in space in 1963. However, women are still significantly less often chosen for space missions than men, making up only 12% of all astronauts who have been to space as of June 2020. Most of the 70 women who have been to space are United States citizens, with other countries sending one, two, or three women on space missions. Women face the same physical and psychological challenges of spaceflight as men, but some studies suggest they may be better suited for longer missions. Despite this, gender discrimination remains a significant obstacle for women in space exploration.

content: 2005年，创作于探索频道的纪实虚构电视特别节目《外星球》根据艺术家和作家韦恩·巴洛（Wayne Barlowe）1990年的著作《远征》创作。《外星球》以自然纪录片的风格，探索了虚构星球达尔文IV上的外星生命。尽管紧随巴洛的对达尔文IV的描述，《外星球》还有一个团队的科学家和科幻人物，讨论达尔文IV的情况，好像它真的被发现了一样。参与其中的人包括迈克尔·卡库、史蒂芬·霍金、杰克·霍纳、詹姆斯·加尔文和乔治·卢卡斯。《外星球》获得了积极的评价，被称为发人深省的节目，不过也有一些批评，关于一些奇怪的生物，一些评论者认为它们接近不可信。

content: "Aurelia and Blue Moon" is a British-American television documentary series that aired in 2005 in the UK and the US. It focuses on the hypothetical evolution of alien life on extrasolar planets, presenting two fictional worlds in its two episodes. The program is based on collaboration between American and British scientists, commissioned by National Geographic, and explores the possibility of extraterrestrial life evolving on a tidally locked planet orbiting a red dwarf star and a large moon orbiting a gas giant in a binary star system. The series uses a combination of accretion theory, climatology, and xenobiology to imagine the most likely locations for extraterrestrial life and its evolutionary path. content:
1964年，由动画师Hubley家族制作的动画电影《星星和人》改编自天文学家哈洛·沙普利于1959年的同名著作，他也是电影的解说员。这部以纪录片风格制作的电影讲述了人类（以一个孩子的形象）通过外太空、物质、生命意义和周期表等主题来寻找自己在宇宙中的位置。电影中没有角色的声音，而是通过他们的动作来“交谈”。它被引用为“动画纪录片”的一个典范。

电影首次在麻省理工学院的视觉学院会议期间进行了放映。公开首映是在1964年4月28日，位于纽约的比克曼剧院，与一系列Hubley / U.P.A.短片（包括《月鸟》和《杰拉尔德·麦克波灵-鲍因》）一起放映。评论普遍积极。

在电影节策展人中存在关于它的类型的争议。在威尼斯电影节上，《星星和人》被放在了真人特辑类别中，而在旧金山电影节上，它参加了纪录片类别并赢得了奖项。

1990年7月，《星星和人》在Buena Vista Home Video发行了VHS版，九年后，Image Entertainment发布了DVD版，作为Hubley制作的一部作品的一部分。

content: Timelapse of the Future: A Journey to the End of Time is a 2019 29-minute short epic documentary film by American filmmaker John D. Boswell. It showcases a flowmotion of the universe from 2019 to the end of time, combining hyper-lapse, time-lapse, and regular shots with a lapse rate doubling every five seconds. The film uses self-made and fair use footage, as well as speeches by scientists, to depict current knowledge and different hypotheses of the universe. Boswell spent six months on production and initially conceived the film as an art installation without dialogue, but later changed it due to the weight of the subject matter. content: White House at Night is an oil painting by Vincent van Gogh, created in 1890 and displayed at the Hermitage Museum. The painting reflects the psychological tension Van Gogh was under before his death, with red splashes on two "eye" windows and a star symbolizing his anguish. According to astronomers, the star is likely Venus, indicating the painting was done around 8:00 PM. The painting was lost after World War II but resurfaced in 1995 as part of an exhibition of looted Soviet artworks, along with three other van Gogh pieces from the same collection.

content: Coldplay's ninth studio album, Music of the Spheres, was released in October 2021. Produced by Max Martin, it features guest appearances from Selena Gomez, We Are King, Jacob Collier, and BTS, as well as contributions from Jon Hopkins. The album is a concept album set in a fictional planetary system called The Spheres, with each track corresponding to a planet. The singles "Higher Power" and "My Universe" received Grammy nominations, with "My Universe" reaching number one on the Billboard Hot 100. The album received mixed reviews, with "Coloratura" receiving critical acclaim. It debuted at number one on the UK Albums Chart and was nominated for Album of the Year and Best Pop Vocal Album at the 65th Annual Grammy Awards. Coldplay embarked on the Music of the Spheres World Tour to support the album.

content:
《火星》是一部由国家地理频道制作的硬科幻电视系列，于2016年11月14日在国家地理频道和FX首播。在官方播出日期之前，它还在2016年11月1日以流媒体格式发布。它将真实采访与虚构的太空飞行员团队登陆火星的故事融合在一起。

该系列根据斯蒂芬·佩特兰尼克的《我们将如何在火星上生活》(2015)改编。虚构叙事最初在2016年和2033年之间交替，使用现实非小说采访来解释故事中的事件。随着系列的发展，虚构叙事逐渐进展到2042年，当时殖民地正在发展。该系列是在布达佩斯和摩洛哥拍摄的。

配套书《火星：我们在红色星球的未来》(2016年10月)详细介绍了该节目背后的科学知识。一部名为《火星之前》的前传剧集与该系列一起制作并发布。它讲述了一个宇航员的生活瞬间，以及她参与科学研究的决定。

总共制作了两季，《火星》于2018年11月12日首播第二季。主演Jihae通过她的官方Instagram确认该系列在播出两季后被取消。

content: Astrosociology is an interdisciplinary study that explores the relationship between outer space, extraterrestrial places, and society. It combines space-related sciences and sociology to understand the impact of human society beyond our current planetary system. The

Extraterrestrial life, or alien life, refers to life that originates from planets other than Earth. Despite extensive speculation and scientific research, no conclusive evidence of extraterrestrial life has been found. The possibility of intelligent extraterrestrial life is a subject of interest in the Drake equation and the field of astrobiology.

The idea of inhabited worlds beyond Earth has been discussed since antiquity, with early Christian writers and thinkers such as Democritus and Augustine considering the possibility. Pre-modern writers often assumed that extraterrestrial worlds are inhabited by living beings. In the 15th century, William Vorilong suggested that Jesus may have visited extraterrestrial worlds to redeem their inhabitants.

The search for signs of extraterrestrial life has intensified since the mid-20th century, using methods ranging from telescope and specimen analysis to radio communication. Scientific research on extreme and chemically harsh ecosystems on Earth, such as hydrothermal vents and acidic hot springs, has provided hope for the possibility of extraterrestrial life, despite the disparity in atmospheric composition and conditions on other planets.

The concept of extraterrestrial life and intelligence has had a significant cultural impact, particularly in fiction, where it has communicated scientific ideas and influenced public interest. There is debate over whether to attempt communication with extraterrestrial intelligence, with some advocating aggressive methods and others warning of potential dangers.

content: The Kármán line, named after Theodore von Kármán, is a conventional definition of the edge of space at an altitude of 100 kilometers (62 miles) above sea level. Although von Kármán initially calculated a theoretical limit for airplane flight at 83.8 km (52.1 mi) above Earth, the later established Kármán line has no distinct physical significance and is subject to disagreement among experts. It is mainly used for legal and regulatory purposes, differentiating between aircraft and spacecraft. While international law does not define the edge of space or the limit of national airspace, most international organizations and regulatory agencies accept the FAI's Kármán line definition. Various countries and entities define space's boundary differently for their own purposes.

content: King of the Universe was a prestigious title used by powerful monarchs in ancient Mesopotamia, claiming dominion over the universe. It is sometimes applied to God in the Abrahamic tradition. The etymology of the title comes from the ancient Sumerian city of Kish, originally meaning "King of Kish." The first ruler to use the title was Sargon of Akkad, and it was used by later empires claiming descent from his Akkadian Empire. The last known ruler to use the title was Antiochus I of the Seleucids. It is possible that the title was earned through successful military campaigns, and it may have had a similar counterpart, "King of the Four Corners of the World." The literal translation of "King of the Universe" exists in many languages. In Hindi, it would be Nikhil Shah, and in Urdu, it would be Shah Jahan.

content: Astronauts have reported unidentified flying objects (UFOs) in space, leading to claims of evidence for extraterrestrial life by ufologists. However, some alleged sightings, such as a hoax perpetuated by science fiction writer Otto Binder, have been proven false. UFO proponents consider comments and photos from NASA as strong evidence, but a 1970 letter from NASA's Robert F. Allnut stated that there was no evidence of extraterrestrial spacecraft after years of space voyages. In 2009, NASA footage posted on YouTube renewed UFO conspiracy theories, and incidents were collected for a 2014 television series episode.

Earth observation satellites are orbiting spacecraft with sensors to collect imagery and data of the Earth's surface. They monitor short-term weather, climate change, and natural disasters, benefiting research subjects like meteorology, oceanography, ecology, and more. Sensors include passive and active remote sensors that measure energy across the electromagnetic spectrum. The use of satellite remote telemetry for climate research began in the 1960s, and political interest in gathering Earth remote-sensing data increased in the 1970s with new scientific evidence of rapid climate changes.

content: This is a partial list of artificial materials left on the Moon, including those from the Apollo program. It does not include tools, retroreflectors, Apollo Lunar Surface Experiments Packages, or personal objects left by astronauts such as flags and plaques. Five S-IVB third stages of Saturn V rockets are the heaviest human-made objects on the lunar surface, totaling over 187,400 kilograms (413,100 lb) of material. The only artificial objects still in use are retroreflectors for Lunar Laser Ranging experiments left by Apollo 11, 14, and 15 astronauts, as well as those left by the Chandrayaan-3 lunar lander and the Soviet Union's Lunokhod 1 and Lunokhod 2 missions. This is a timeline of the first orbital launches by country. As of 2022, eleven countries, including the United States, Japan, China, India, Iran, Israel, France, the United Kingdom, South Korea, Russia, and Ukraine, have the capability to send objects into orbit with their own launch vehicles. In addition, Canada, Australia, Germany, Brazil, Algeria, Kazakhstan, Turkey, Argentina, Italy, Malaysia, Poland, South Africa, the Philippines, Egypt, Spain, Mexico, Thailand, and Chile have built or launched satellites.

Russia and Ukraine inherited their space launch capabilities from the Soviet Union. Russia launches its rockets from its own and foreign (Kazakh) spaceports, while Ukraine launched from foreign (Kazakh and Russian) facilities until 2015 when political differences with Russia halted Ukraine's ability to produce orbital rockets.

content:
The Apollo program was a US human spaceflight initiative from 1961 to 1972, landing the first astronauts on the Moon using Saturn IB and Saturn V rockets. Uncrewed test flights in 1966 validated the safety of the launch vehicles and spacecraft, with crewed missions from October 1968 showing their ability to carry out lunar landings.

Apollo 11 achieved the first crewed lunar landing in 1969, with subsequent missions landing on various lunar sites until December 1972. Twelve men walked on the Moon and 842 pounds of lunar rocks and soil samples were returned to Earth, contributing to the understanding of the Moon's composition and geological history.

Two missions failed: a 1967 cabin fire killed the entire Apollo 1 crew, and the Apollo 13 mission was aborted by an oxygen tank explosion en route to the Moon. The crew circled the Moon and were returned safely to Earth using the LM Aquarius as a "lifeboat" for essential functions.

The Artemis program is a U.S. human spaceflight program aimed at reestablishing a human presence on the Moon, with long-term goals of extracting lunar resources and enabling crewed missions to Mars. The program includes crewed and robotic exploration of the lunar surface, with three planned Orion missions in the early 2020s. In addition, Commercial Lunar Payload Services (CLPS) will launch supporting scientific and technology demonstration missions, along with uncrewed logistical missions to construct and resupply the Gateway and lunar landers in lunar orbit.

content: The European Space Agency (ESA) conducts a variety of missions in collaboration with other national space agencies such as JAXA, CNES, ASI, DLR, NASA, and CNSA. These include both operational and scientific missions, as well as public-private partnership missions with European satellite operators. The ESA's Science Doctrine is represented by the Cosmic Vision programme, which focuses on space science missions related to the Solar System and interstellar astronomy. The Living Planet Programme, focused on Earth observation, has launched various "Earth Explorers" to study geoscience. Additionally, the ESA has launched and operated missions such as Giotto, Ulysses, and Mars Express outside of a formal programme.

content: Uncrewed spaceflights to the ISS primarily deliver cargo. Russian modules also dock to the outpost after uncrewed launches. Resupply missions use Russian Progress spacecraft, European Automated Transfer Vehicles, Japanese Kounotori, and American Dragon and Cygnus spacecraft. Progress uses the automated Kurs system, with TORU as backup. ATVs use Kurs but not TORU. HTV, CRS Dragon, and Cygnus rendezvous and are grappled by Canadarm2 before docking for one to two months. Progress, Cygnus, and ATV can remain docked for up to six months. Cargo Dragon docks autonomously under CRS phase 2. As of December 2022, Progress spacecraft have flown most uncrewed missions t

content:
Human exploration of the Moon has involved numerous space missions to study Earth's natural satellite. The Soviet Union's Luna 2 was the first spacecraft to successfully impact the Moon in 1959, followed by Luna 9 achieving the first controlled soft landing and Luna 10 entering orbit. In 1968, the Zond 5 mission carried lifeforms (tortoises) close to the Moon.

From 1968 to 1972, the United States conducted crewed missions as part of the Apollo program, with Apollo 8 being the first to enter orbit, and Apollo 11 landing the first humans on the Moon, including Neil Armstrong, the first person to walk on it. The Apollo 13 mission had to forgo its landing due to a spacecraft malfunction, but all ten crewed missions returned safely to Earth.

The Soviet Union also conducted uncrewed missions deploying rovers and returning samples, with three rover missions and eleven sample return flights attempted.

In 2018, China's Chang'e 4 mission soft-landed on the far side of the Moon, exploring the South Pole–Aitken basin and deploying the Yutu rover. In 2024, China successfully landed the Chang'e 6 mission in the Apollo crater on the far side, collecting lunar samples.

content: Nine spacecraft have been launched to visit the outer planets, all involving encounters with Jupiter, with four also visiting Saturn. Voyager 2 also visited Uranus and Neptune. Two missions, Ulysses and New Horizons, flew past Jupiter en route to the Sun and Pluto, respectively. Cassini–Huygens also used Jupiter for a gravity assist on its way to Saturn. content:
自 1978 年以来，Progress 自动飞船进行了一系列任务。Progress 是一艘无人驾驶的俄罗斯（前苏联）货运飞船，用于向苏联空间站 Salyut 6、Salyut 7、Mir 和后来的国际空间站运送物资，所有发射都发生在拜科努尔航天发射场。

已经发射了超过 178 次飞行，除 Progress M-12M、Progress M-27M 和 Progress MS-04/65P 外，其余都抵达了目的地，在发射后没有伤亡或生命损失；Progress M-12M 和 MS-04 在发射过程中失败，而 Progress M-27M 在轨道飞行时出现了航天器姿态控制丢失。1994 年，Progress M-24 飞船在未能对接成功时与 Mir 空间站发生碰撞，1997 年，Progress M-34 在对接测试中偏离轨道，导致了对 Spektr 模块的严重损坏。

该飞船使用自动 Kurs 对接系统与目标太空站对接，只有在出现问题时，机组人员才会用手动 TORU 系统进行干预。到目前为止，已经飞行了五种 Progress 飞船变体：Progress 7K-TG（1978–1990）、Progress-M 11F615A55（1989–2009）、Progress-M1（2000–2004）、Progress-М 11F615A60（2008–2015）和 Progress-MS（自 2015 年以来）。此外，还发射了三种定制的 Progress M 变体，以运送国际空间站模块 Pirs（2001 年）、Poisk（2009 年）和 Prichal（2021 年末）。

content: The Soyuz programme, initiated by the Soviet Union in the 1960s, was intended for a Moon landing. It is the third Soviet human spaceflight programme after Vostok and Voskhod. Russia continued and expanded the programme after the Soviet Union's dissolution. The Soyuz spacecraft has visited the Salyut and Mir space stations and now plays a vital role in transporting crews to the International Space Station. Russia plans to replace Soyuz with the Federatsiya/Orel programme in the 2020s, which will use reusable capsules launching on

content: The Space Shuttle, operated by NASA, was a reusable spacecraft system for low Earth orbit. It launched satellites, conducted experiments, and serviced the ISS. From 1981 to 2011, 135 missions were flown from Kennedy Space Center, totaling over 1,300 days of flight time. The program flew 355 people from 16 countries and included 852 total shuttle fliers. The shuttles docked with the Russian space station Mir nine times and visited the ISS thirty-seven times. The first orbiter built, Enterprise, was used for flight tests. Four operational orbiters were built: Columbia, Challenger, Discovery, and Atlantis. Challenger and Columbia were destroyed in accidents in 1986 and 2003, killing fourteen astronauts. A fifth orbiter, Endeavour, was built to replace Challenger. The Space Shuttle was retired from service after STS-135 in July 2011.

content: Axiom Space has designed the Axiom Orbital Segment, intended for commercial space activities and space tourism on the International Space Station (ISS). NASA approved the project in January 2020, and the segment is planned to become its own space station, Axiom Station. It is uncertain which launch vehicles will be used for these modules. Up to three modules are set to be attached to the ISS, with the first expected to launch no earlier than late 2026 and dock to the forward port of Harmony. Axiom Space plans to add two more modules and send private astronauts to inhabit the space. R

content:
This is a list of crewed spacecraft types that have flown into space, including sub-orbital flights above 80 km, visited space stations, and future crewed spacecraft. It does not include uncrewed spacecraft or crewed flights below 80 km. There is debate over the height of space, but this article uses 80 km as the threshold.

Since Vostok 1 in 1961, there have been 13 types of crewed spacecraft – nine American, three Russian, and one Chinese. There are currently five operational crewed spacecraft, eight retired types, and spacecraft in development. There are two space stations in orbit – the International Space Station and the Chinese Tiangong.

Crewed spacecraft must support human life and have a human-rating certification. They must have a breathable atmosphere, pressurization, and temperature regulation. Crewed spacecraft include space capsules, spaceplanes, and space stations.

content: Dragon, also known as Dragon 1 or Cargo Dragon, was a series of 14 partially reusable cargo spacecraft developed by SpaceX between 2010 and 2020. Launched by the Falcon 9, it resupplied the International Space Station (ISS) and made history by becoming the first commercially built and operated spacecraft to be successfully recovered from orbit in December 2010. It also became the first commercial spacecraft to rendezvous with and attach to the ISS in 2012. SpaceX delivered cargo to the ISS under NASA's Commercial Resupply Services program and flew regular cargo missions starting in October 2012. The last flight of the Dragon 1 spacecraft took place on March 7, 2020, marking the retirement of the Dragon 1 fleet and the transition to the Cargo Dragon variant of the SpaceX Dragon 2 spacecraft for future comme
categories: Supply vehicles for the International Space Station
see_also: Comparison of space station cargo vehicles

content: Dragon 2, developed by SpaceX, is a reusable spacecraft for flights to the International Space Station. It comes in two variants: Crew Dragon, which can carry a crew of four, and Cargo Dragon, used for freight. The spacecraft launches on a Falcon 9 rocket and returns to Earth through splashdown. It is the most cost-effective spacecraft used by NASA. Cargo Dragon supplies cargo to the ISS and is the only reusable orbital cargo spacecraft in operation. Crew Dragon is the only U.S. human-rated orbital transport spacecraft, transporting crews to and from the ISS. It also supports commercial flights and is expected to shuttle people to and from Axiom Space's planned space station.
categories: Supply vehicles for the International Space Station
see_also: Comparison of space station cargo vehicles

content: Since June 2010, SpaceX's Falcon 9 family has had 354 launches, with 352 successful missions, two failures, and one partial success. It includes retired versions and the currently active Block 5. The design features reusable first-stage boosters, which have successfully landed 318 times in 329 attempts. SpaceX has also reflown fairing halves more than 300 times. The rockets have launched Starlink satellites, Dragon crew and cargo missions to the ISS, and commercial and military satellites to various orbits. The heaviest payloads launched on Falcon are batches of 24 Starlink V2-Mini satellites. The heaviest payload launched to GTO was the Jupiter-3. Launches to higher orbits have included missions to the Sun-Earth Lagrange points and to asteroids like Didymos and 16 Psyche.

content: SpaceX manufactures and operates Falcon 9 Block 5 and Falcon Heavy launch vehicles powered by Merlin engines and VTVL technologies for reuse. The company is also developing the fully reusable Starship system to replace its current vehicles by 2024. Falcon 1, the company's first launch vehicle, was the first privately developed liquid-fueled launch vehicle to reach orbit and was used for five launches between 2006 and 2009. The Falcon 9 v1.0 was developed for the US Air Force and NASA programs, later replaced by the Falcon 9 v1.1 series in 2013. This was followed by the Falcon 9 Full Thrust and Falcon Heavy variants in 2015 and 2018, with launches from various locations.

content: Starship is a spacecraft developed by SpaceX to transport crew and cargo to destinations such as Earth orbit, the Moon, and Mars. It is designed for long duration interplanetary flights and can accommodate up to 100 people. Additionally, it will enable point-to-point transport on Earth, with the ability to travel anywhere in the world in less than an hour. The spacecraft will also be used to refuel other Starship vehicles for higher orbits and space destinations. Development began in 2012, and the first successful flight of the Starhopper prototype occurred in 2019. Subsequent prototypes, including Ship 24, Ship 25, and Ship 28, have undergone various tests and flights. Elon Musk announced updated versions of Starship, V2 and V3, in 2024, with increased capabilities.

SpaceX has conducted 15 flight tests of prototype rockets for the Starship launch vehicle development program from 2019 to 2024. The tests included low-altitude flights for single-stage Starship spacecraft and orbital trajectory flights for the entire Starship launch vehicle. None of the flights have carried an operational payload yet, and more tests are planned for 2024.

The prototype vehicles flown so far include Starhopper, SN5, SN6, SN8, SN9, SN10, SN11, SN15, Ship 24/B7, Ship 25/B9, Ship 28/B10, and Ship 29/B11. The Starship is a fully-reusable two-stage super heavy-lift launch vehicle designed to take people to Mars and beyond, with the upp

content:
Government space agencies are established by countries or regional groupings to advocate for and engage in activities related to outer space. These agencies serve national prestige, exploitation of remote sensing information, communications, education, and economic development. Examples include NASA, ESA, JAXA, Roscosmos, ISRO, and CNSA.

The listings of government space agencies provide a comparative summary of capabilities across countries and regional authorities. They are segregated to show progression in complexity and capacity, including the establishment of the agency, development of launch capability, capacity for extraterrestrial exploration, and demonstration of human spaceflight capability.

The fifth listing identifies countries considering or developing space agency organizations but have not ratified formation or operation. The demonstrated capabilities represent national or regional capacity to achieve the identified objectives, and do not determine unique funding sources.

It is noted that many space programs involve cooperation between civil agencies and military organizations to support space programs given the geographical expanse required for successful operation.

content:
罕见的陨石空爆是陨石进入行星大气层后爆炸的一种类型。这种命运使它们被称为火球或火流星，最明亮的空爆被称为超级火流星。这些陨石最初是几到几十米直径的小行星和彗星，与更小更常见的“流星”，通常在进入大气层时就会迅速燃烧，形成了鲜明对比。

近代最强大的陨石空爆是1908年的通古斯事件。在这次事件中，一颗直径约50-60米的石头状陨石在西伯利亚一个人烟稀少的森林上空以5-10公里的高度爆炸。产生的冲击波摧毁了约光滑面积达2150平方公里的8000万棵树，并可能造成了3人死亡。

非常明亮的火流星在天空中飞过时会经常被看到，比如1947年的辽宁冷山火流星和2013年的车里雅宾斯克火流星，都发生在俄罗斯。如果火流星足够大，其碎片可能会幸存下来，像这样的陨石。通过CTBTO的远程探测和红外线、卫星技术的进步，增加了空爆的检测可能性。

This article compares active and upcoming orbital launch systems. For retired systems, see Comparison of retired orbital launch systems. The comparison lists the attributes of current and future individual rocket configurations designed to reach orbit. The first list includes operational rockets as of 2024 and those that have attempted an orbital flight, while the second list includes upcoming rockets. For a simple list of all conventional launcher families, see Comparison of orbital launchers families. For predominantly solid-fueled systems, see Comparison of solid-fueled orbital launch systems.

content: This is a list of artificial objects reentering Earth's atmosphere by mass. Most objects are destroyed by reentry heating, but some survive, often breaking up into smaller pieces. The list includes 134 Space Shuttle external tanks used between 1981 and 2011, which broke apart before impacting the ocean. The tanks' mass varied over the years and they were not necessarily completely empty when discarded. Other launch systems have also discarded spent stages into space, but not all stages reach orbit or even space. content:
自20世纪中期航天时代开始以来，美国已经开发了许多太空项目。政府通过三个主要机构运行太空项目：NASA负责民用太空；美国太空部队负责军事太空；国家侦察办公室负责情报太空。这些机构已经投入了大量资源，以推进技术方法以实现目标。在20世纪80年代末，商业利益在太空行业中出现并急剧扩张，特别是在过去的10至15年内。

NASA提供了美国太空计划中最显眼的元素。从载人太空探索和阿波罗11号登月任务，到航天飞机、国际空间站、旅行者号、火星探测器、众多太空望远镜和阿尔忒弥斯计划，NASA履行了民用太空探索的任务。NASA还与其他美国民用机构合作，如国家海洋和大气管理局（NOAA）和美国地质调查局（USGS），为这些组织的天气和民用遥感任务提供太空资产支持。2022年，NASA的年度预算约为240亿美元。

国防部负责军事太空计划。2019年，美国太空部队开始成为主要的国防部代理机构，负责提供军事太空能力。例如全球定位系统，为全球用户所普遍使用，是由国防部开发并维护。导弹预警、防御天气、军事卫星通信和空间域感知也获得了重大的年度投资。2023年，国防部针对太空的年度预算请求为245亿美元。

情报界，包括国家侦察办公室在内的实体在太空领域投入了大量资源。监视和侦察是这些实体的主要关注点。

美国的商业太空活动得到了1984年10月《商业航天发射法案》的通过。商业载人计划的活动得到了1996年5月1000万美元的安萨里X奖的设立的推动。

content: The Astrovan, also known as the astronaut transfer van, was used by NASA at the Kennedy Space Center to transport astronauts to the launch pad and back for Space Shuttle missions. Despite being old, early shuttle astronauts liked its history and tradition, and even opposed getting a new one. During the twenty-minute drive to the launch pad, the van would stop at least once for an astronaut to assess the weather conditions. Senior NASA managers occasionally rode along and were dropped off at the Launch Control Center.

content: Bonnor–Ebert mass is the largest mass for an isothermal gas sphere in hydrostatic equilibrium within a pressurized medium in astrophysics. Clouds with greater masses will collapse gravitationally to form smaller, denser objects, making it a crucial quantity in star formation study. For a gas cloud in a medium with gas pressure 𝑝0, the Bonnor–Ebert mass is given by a formula involving the gravitational constant, isothermal sound speed, and a dimensionless constant 𝑎, which varies based on the density distribution of the cloud.

content: Bordeaux Segalen University, also known as University of Victor Segalen Bordeaux II, specialized in Life and Health Sciences and Human and Social Sciences. It merged with Bordeaux 1 and Bordeaux 4 in 2014 to form University of Bordeaux. The university consisted of various UFRs, institutes, and a renowned oenological institute. It was also involved in a project with the European Space Agency to develop surgical robots for use in space.

content: A closed ecological system is an ecosystem that does not rely on exchanging matter with the outside. Often used for small, man-made ecosystems, they are of scientific interest and may support life during space flights. In these systems, waste products from one species must be used by another, such as converting carbon dioxide and waste into food and water. They must also contain at least one autotrophic organism, commonly green algae.

E-USOC, part of Polytechnic University of Madrid, focuses on space science R&D. It supports Spanish user teams conducting experiments in microgravity on the International Space Station. E-USOC also assists researchers and groups interested in space sciences and fluid mechanics. It is based at Campus de Montegancedo, a research park in Pozuelo de Alarcón, Madrid. Pedro Duque, a Spanish astronaut and former Minister of Science, served as E-USOC's operations director from 2003-2006.

content: The European Astronaut Centre (EAC) is part of the European Space Agency and is home to the European Astronaut Corps. It is located near Cologne, Germany, and has six divisions for astronaut training, space medicine, astronaut management, lunar exploration, and communications. EAC provides training facilities for European and international partner astronauts, including a neutral buoyancy pool for spacewalk practice. It is also responsible for organizing the training of European astronauts at partner centers in the US, Russia, Canada, and Japan. content: Expedition 43 to the International Space Station began on March 11, 2015 and ended on June 11, 2015. The crew had to stay an extra month due to a cargo spacecraft failure and also adjusted the orbit to avoid space debris. They tested the ISSpresso machine and a special cup for drinking in microgravity, building on earlier zero gravity cup experiments in 2008. The new cup was developed by a Fluid physicist at Portland State University.

content: Haven-1, a planned space station in low Earth orbit, is being developed by American aerospace company Vast and is set to launch no earlier than August 2025 atop a SpaceX Falcon 9. The first mission, Vast-1, will carry four astronauts on a Crew Dragon spacecraft for a thirty-day stay. Additional Crew Dragon launches will transport astronauts to and from the station during its lifespan. The station will rely on Crew Dragon for long-term missions, with life support systems to sustain 4-crew missions, communication facilitie

The Immortality Drive is a large memory device taken to the International Space Station in 2008. It contains digitized DNA sequences of humans like physicist Stephen Hawking, comedian Stephen Colbert, and athlete Lance Armstrong, as well as a copy of George's Secret Key to the Universe. The drive aims to preserve human DNA in case of a global cataclysm. It was featured in History Channel's Life After People.

content: Launch Complex 48 (LC-48) is a multi-user launch site for small launchers and spacecraft, located south of Launch Complex 39A and north of Space Launch Complex 41. Construction began in November 2019 but was halted in March 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic and resumed in June 2020, with the first pad completed in October 2020. LC-48 is designed as a "clean pad" for multiple launch systems with different propellant needs and is capable of being expanded to two pads in the future. content: Kosmos 382, a Soviet Soyuz 7K-L1E spacecraft, was successfully test launched into Low Earth Orbit on December 2, 1970. The mission's main goal was to test the N1/L3 spacecraft's Block D lunar orbit insertion/descent stage by simulating the lunar orbit insertion burn, the lunar orbit circularization burn and the final lunar descent burn. Lagrange point colonization is a proposed form of space colonization that involves the establishment of colonies at the five equilibrium points in the orbit of a planet or its primary moon. The Lagrange points L4 and L5 are stable if the mass of the larger body is at least 25 times the mass of the secondary body, making them potential sites for space colonies. Gerard K. Malargüe Station, also known as DSA 3, is a 35-metre ESTRACK radio antenna in Argentina that enables the European Space Agency to communicate with spacecraft in deep space. Located 40 kilometers south of Malargüe, it has two sister stations in Spain and Australia, completing the ESTRACK network for continuous tracking of deep space missions. The station's 35-meter dish antenna was hoisted into place in 2011 and underwent tests in 2012 before becoming fully operational in 2013. It provided communications, tracking, and data download from the Rosetta spacecraft. The station features a 20kW CW High Power Amplifier created by Rhein

content: Moving Earth is a theoretical astroengineering concept to shift our planet farther away from the Sun and protect it from rising temperatures due to the greenhouse effect and the Sun's increasing luminosity. The approach has been acknowledged by some scientists, but has practical drawbacks. The proposed method involves redirecting asteroids or comets around Earth's orbit and towards Jupiter or Saturn to gradually move Earth away from the Sun, keeping it habitable. However, this long-term plan poses risks, such as potential loss of the Moon and disruptions to Earth's climate and rotation. Lengthening Earth's orbital period could also disrupt global seasonal weather patterns. The close encounters with asteroids or comets could also end most life on the planet if not carefully calculated.

content: Aerospace Week, established in 2010, celebrates aerospace in the United States and is supported by government and private organizations, including NASA and the U.S. Department of Commerce. It was established by an agreement between the U.S. Congress and the Aerospace Industries Association. In 2014, the Governor of Utah and the U.S. Secretary of Commerce honored the aerospace industry during the week. National Aerospace Week's contributions to national security and economic prosperity were recognized in a statement by the U.S. Secretary of Commerce. Additionally, in 2017, the U.S. Department of Commerce recognized Aerospace Week through a letter from Secretary Wilbur Ross. In addition to Aerospace Week, NASA also celebrates National Aviation Day, established in 1939.

content:
The neutral body posture (NBP) is the natural posture the human body takes in microgravity, minimizing the need for muscular effort. NASA developed the Man-System Integration Standards (MSIS) in the 1980s, based on measurements of crew members in microgravity, to define an average NBP. Still photographs from Skylab showed a distinct posture with raised arms, abducted shoulders, flexed knees, and plantar flexed feet. Research on Space Shuttle mission STS-57 found greater individual variations in NBP than the Skylab study suggested, with three main postures exhibited by the crew as a whole. These differences could be due to athletic bearing, type and amount of exercise, past physical injuries, and gender differences. No single crew member exhibited the typical NBP per MSIS standards.

The neutral body posture occurs in weightlessness, relieving musculoskeletal stress and reducing pressure on the diaphragm and spine. It supports the natural curvature of the spine, curving inward at the neck, outward at the upper back, and inward at the lower back. NASA standards for NBP have influenced seat design for commercial vehicles, with Nissan Motor Company using N

content: The LORAX was an experimental robotics project developed by the Robotics Institute of Carnegie Mellon University and supported by NASA. Its goal was to create an autonomous rover to survey the distribution of microbes on Antarctica's ice sheets. The robot was designed to have full navigational autonomy and operate unattended for one month without human intervention. It used a combination of solar power and wind power for sustainable energy, including solar panels and a deployable wind turbine. A working model called Nomad was tested in 2005 on a frozen lake in New Hampshire, successfully completing a ten kilometer test run and conducting a test of its wind turbine. In 1969, two NASA engineers were awarded for preventing the collapse and explosion of an Atlas rocket. content: The ORNL DAAC (Oak Ridge National Laboratory Distributed Active Archive Center) is a data center managed by NASA as part of the Earth Observing System Data and Information System (EOSDIS). Established in 1993 and operated by Oak Ridge National Laboratory in Tennessee, it focuses on data related to terrestrial biogeochemistry, ecology, and environmental processes. The center's mission is to assemble, distribute, and provide data services for a comprehensive archive of terrestrial biogeochemistry and ecological dynamics observations and models to support research, education, and decision-making in NASA's Earth Science. The ORNL DAAC is listed in the Registry of Research Data Repositories and is a member of the ISC World Data System.

content: An aerogravity assist (AGA) is a theoretical spacecraft maneuver designed to change velocity upon arrival at a planet with an atmosphere. Unlike a pure gravity assist, which relies solely on a planet's gravity to change trajectory, an AGA involves dipping into the planet's atmosphere to use aerodynamic lift and gravity to further curve the spacecraft's path, resulting in a higher change in velocity. This allows for shorter travel times, a larger payload fraction, or a smaller spacecraft for a given payload. The goal of AGA is to achieve a larger change in direction by using the planet's atmosphere, as opposed to using it to slow the spacecraft down. Whil

Areosynchronous orbits (ASO) are the martian equivalent of geosynchronous orbits (GSO) on Earth, named after the ancient Greek god Ares. Satellites in ASO have an orbital period equal to Mars' sidereal day and an altitude of 17,000 kilometers. An areostationary orbit (AEO) is a type of ASO that appears fixed in the sky to an observer on the surface of Mars. While no satellites currently occupy ASO or AEO, some scientists foresee a future telecommunications network for the exploration of Mars.
